content:
In the statement it is ask to round the mean to the nearest integer but in you use the round function from python which is a round to the even not a round to the nearest.

If you use round to the nearest tests 3 and 4 will fail because of that

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice little exercise for statistics

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it is vey challenging

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good CoC !
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Quite interesting as a way to get an interval.
A good challenge, but I think it can be written more concise for fastest-class Clash of Code purpose.

What's more, it could be great to replace mean(X) in your MAD description by M since what is used is mean rounded and not true mean.

Finally, is the printed sentence necessary ? Generally speaking, fastest-class Clash of Codes do not ask such verbose. Same goes for golf code.

Anyway good job it's a very pleasant problem, in both fastest and golf code

I like when you learn something from the clashes. I've never heard of MAD outlier detection. 
My only remark is, that you could change the stub to:
> read n:int
> loopline n x:int
> write Values less than inf or greater than sup are rejected.

There is some ambiguity in your example. You say that MAD = median( | Xi - median(X) | ).
But in the example, you wrote
1. M = mean(X) = (1+2+3+5+4) / 5 = 3
2. MAD = median ( ||1-3|, |2-3|, |3-3|, |5-3|, |4-3|)......
Should we use the mean or the median? Maybe use an example where they are not equals?

Thanks a lot for pointing this out !
Indeed, I should've written that the median of average deviations is:
MAD = median( abs( X[i] - mean(X) ) ).
I made the correction and also changed the example such that mean and median of deviations are not equal.
Does it look better now?

Thank you for your remark ! I'll update it to be integers in loop.
Glad you learned something through this.

Good points, thank you !
I'll edit it bearing in mind the feedbacks.

Well, the round function always round to the nearest integer (wether it is a positive or negative number). The rounding to the even is only in the case of the exact half (midpoint between two successive integers). For every integer n, round(2n + 0.5) = 2n and round(2n + 1 + 0.5) = 2n also (instead of 2n+1).
Examples:
round(7.4) = 7
round(7.55) = 8
round(-7.55) = -8
round(7.5) = round(8.5) = 8.
round(-7.5) = round(-8.5) = -8.

For this CoC, the mean never falls exactly at n.5 so there is no problem imo and the tests will not fail even with this subtle behavior of the function round.
Sorry for the noise, I was doing rounding half up not to the nearest
No worries, thank you for your contribution :-)
